parameters.content:
# üõ†Ô∏è Tool Actions & Response Template
**Welcome!** This template helps you design and implement tool actions with consistent response handling.

**üéØ Purpose:**
‚Ä¢ Provide a ready-to-use structure for tool integrations
‚Ä¢ Standardize success, error, and retry responses
‚Ä¢ Ensure clean conditional logic for different outcomes
‚Ä¢ Make tool workflows predictable and reusable

**üöÄ How to Use:** Use this template as your starting point for building reliable tool action workflows.

# üîç Before Implementation, validate the following:

‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ API endpoints documented & accessible
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Response schemas mapped out
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Error scenarios identified
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Fallback strategies planned

# üîÄ Event Options: With or Without Condition  

## **1Ô∏è‚É£ Event With Condition**  
‚Ä¢ Use this when the outcome (Event of the tool) depends on a rule.  
‚Ä¢ Example: ‚ÄúIf the tool argument X = true, then continue. Otherwise, go to error.‚Äù  
‚Ä¢ The condition is checked against the response field, using equals/greater/contains depending on the rule.  
‚Ä¢ You can add a new condition by duplicating this node and connecting it to the trigger. 



















## **2Ô∏è‚É£ Event Without Condition**  
‚Ä¢ Use this when you want the workflow to continue regardless of the tool‚Äôs response.  
‚Ä¢ You can skip the condition step and move directly to the next action.

# üåê API Calls  

‚Ä¢ An event‚Äôs action can be **one API call** or **multiple API calls**.  
‚Ä¢ Run them **in parallel** if they don‚Äôt depend on each other.  
‚Ä¢ Run them **sequentially** if the output of one API is needed as the input for the next.  

For a detailed tutorial on how to use APIs, please invest some time in learning this tutorial: https://n8n.io/workflows/5171-learn-api-fundamentals-with-an-interactive-hands-on-tutorial-workflow/

# üß© Conditions on API Responses  

‚Ä¢ You can add conditions based on the API response.  
‚Ä¢ Make sure you know the possible response formats in advance (or at least the scenarios you care about).  
‚Ä¢ The API output is visible when you run the previous node, and it will appear as the input to this conditional block.

# Ô∏è‚ö° Actions & Tool Response
 
Each condition decides the next step, it can be a combination of the following:  

## **1Ô∏è‚É£ Action**  
‚Ä¢ Continue with another automated step.  
‚Ä¢ Example: ‚ÄúIf response.status = success ‚Üí send confirmation email.‚Äù  

## **2Ô∏è‚É£ Transfer to Human Agent**  
‚Ä¢ Route the flow to a person when automation isn‚Äôt enough.  
‚Ä¢ Example: ‚ÄúIf response.error_code = AUTH_FAILED ‚Üí hand over to support agent.‚Äù  

## **3Ô∏è‚É£ Other**  
‚Ä¢ Handle special cases that don‚Äôt fit standard paths.  
‚Ä¢ Example: ‚ÄúIf response contains warning ‚Üí log it and continue workflow.‚Äù  

## **4Ô∏è‚É£ Tool Response**  
‚Ä¢ Use the raw tool output as a branch in the flow.  
‚Ä¢ Example: ‚ÄúIf response.message = ‚Äòout of office‚Äô ‚Üí trigger follow-up email.‚Äù  

üìå Tip: Make sure you know the tool‚Äôs possible responses in advance, so you 
can set rules for all important scenarios. The output of the API will appear here as 
the input for these conditions.

# üîó Merging Tool Responses  

Now we merge all your tool responses.  
Only the **conditions that are satisfied** will be included in the merge.  

The merged output is then sent back to the bot as the final response.  

‚öôÔ∏è You can change the number of inputs by double-clicking the node and updating the field **‚ÄúNumber of Inputs‚Äù**.  

Check out the Sample tool "get_weather" below.

nodes.name: üß™ Tool Arguments (Defaults)
nodes.notes: Mimics tool arguments so you can click Execute without sending a payload.

nodes.name: üó∫Ô∏è Geocode City (Open-Meteo)
nodes.notes: Returns coordinates for the requested city. No auth needed.

nodes.name: üå§Ô∏è Current Weather (Open-Meteo)
nodes.notes: Returns current temperature and wind speed. No auth needed.

nodes.name: ‚úÖ Action: Create Warm Notice (JSONPlaceholder)
nodes.notes: No auth. Demonstrates an action when a condition is met.

nodes.name: üì© Tool Response (Warm Action)
nodes.notes: Here we include tool_response from the action.

nodes.name: üìù Warm = False (No Tool Response)
nodes.notes: This branch intentionally DOES NOT include a tool_response.

nodes.name: üîó Final Tool Response (append)
nodes.notes: Appends outputs from all satisfied branches. Increase inputs by double-clicking and changing ‚ÄúNumber of Inputs‚Äù.

nodes.name: üìù Warm = True
nodes.notes: This branch intentionally DOES NOT include a tool_response.
